executive_summary: While many businesses struggled to adapt to shifting landscapes amid the pandemic and volatile economic conditions, customer care centers handled things relatively well. With easily adaptable workplace setups, many centers transitioned to work-from-home offices with ease. As a result, revenue inched upward in 2020. When the US economy recovered from COVID-19, corporate profit and consumer spending expanded, boosting downstream demand for the industry's services and causing revenue to jump in 2021 and 2022. Rising interest rates induced recessionary fears, causing businesses to become more conservative in their spending, which hindered investment in the industry's services. Offshoring has become more important in the past few years as companies have sought to reduce labor costs, presenting a major threat to call centers.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: When the pandemic hit, businesses were forced to shut down or significantly curtail their operations in accordance with social distancing regulations. This severely constrained consumer spending and corporate profit, giving businesses fewer funds to spend on customer care centers. As a result, demand for the industry's services dropped.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: REVENUE HAS BEEN QUITE VOLATILE SINCE THE END OF THE PANDEMIC
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: As mass vaccination enabled businesses to eliminate social distancing restrictions, consumer spending and corporate profit soared. This encouraged businesses to raise their investment in customer care services, causing revenue to shoot up in 2021 and 2022. High inflation has caused the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates over the past few years. The elevated cost of borrowing has constrained consumer demand, threatening to put the economy into a recession. Recessionary fears have made businesses more weary of making investments in discretionary services since they want to save money to preserve profit in case of a major economic downturn. As a result, demand for customer care services has declined over the past couple of years, resulting in a drop in revenue in 2023.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Stable Economic Growth Will Benefit Providers
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Despite current challenges related to high inflation, rising interest rates and recessionary fears, the US economy will perform well during the outlook period. As stable economic growth fosters higher consumer spending and corporate profit, downstream demand for customer care centers will rise, causing revenue to expand.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Specialization Will Help Domestic Care Centers Remain Attractive Options
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Technology businesses and financial institutions are a key source of revenue for customer care centers. To keep these clients, care centers must invest in training their employees to provide top-tier service to customers, outperforming overseas operations. Debt collection and other basic services will increasingly be outsourced to offshore operations, as little technical knowledge is needed to accomplish these tasks.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: The Best Care Centers Will Implement New Technology
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Developments in automated technology and artificial intelligence will speed up during the outlook period. Rather than run from the changes, successful care centers will embrace these technologies by using them to enhance the services they offer. Physical employees will always be required in some capacity, but many providers will reduce their reliance on large workforces with technological innovations. Integrating these technologies will increase capital expenses, which are typically low, so profit will dip before stabilizing.

industry_definition: Customer care centers are dedicated facilities where customer service representatives handle inquiries, complaints and provide support to customers. In the United States, these centers play an important role in maintaining customer satisfaction and loyalty across various industries, including retail, telecommunications, finance, healthcare and technology.

negative_impact_factors: low - steady Barriers To Entry Level

threats: Low Outlier Growth - Private investment in computers and software

key_trends: Internal competition is fierce. The most successful customer care centers tend to cater to specific verticals of markets, specializing in specific services. Others opt for a wide-range of services, but these tend to be the largest players.

Many care centers compete based on quality of service. Downstream businesses have many options when choosing customer care centers, including substitutes such as internal divisions, so the most successful centers typically boast reliable, highly skilled employees.

Customer care centers easily adapted to work-from-home setups. Although the pandemic disrupted operations for many businesses, the relatively simple office setups of many customer care centers enabled them to reverse negative revenue trends in 2020.

Revenue will expand during the outlook period as steady economic growth will foster elevated corporate profit and consumer spending will boost downstream demand for the industry's services. Providers will also use new technology to their advantage.

The average customer call center is relatively small, with few exceptions. Most call centers employ fewer than 50 full-time employees and rely on part-time workers. The largest companies, such as Td Synnex, have workforces exceeding 20,000, enabling them to outperform much of the competition.

The largest customer call centers have a global presence. While the average call center operates on a regional or state level, the most significant players have operations across the globe, enabling them to garner lower average wage costs and entice businesses with a wider range of services.

Regulations are varied and mostly aimed at protecting consumers and workers. Still, many less reputable customer call centers neglect such policies, resulting in a continued tightening of the regulatory environment.
Assistance is limited and mostly comes in the form of private associations. One private organization that aids customer care centers is the Professional Association for Customer Engagement (PACE).

Profit is low and volatile. Returns are highly contingent on downstream business performance. If major markets are performing well, they may opt to open internal call centers; if market are performing too poorly, they may forgo call center applications altogether.

Wages are high since customer call centers rely on physical workers and compete based on quality of service. Compensation's revenue share has crept downward during the current period as automated technologies have reduced reliance on some mundane tasks.

The Southeast region is home to the highest share of customer care centers because of the region's large population and relatively low rent costs. Florida is a hotbed for providers since many different types of businesses operate in the state.

Nascent customer care centers often opt to operate from remote locations to reduce rent and utility costs. For this reason, big cities, which tend to have higher operating costs, attract only the largest players.
Tech companies receive a high volume of questions from customers, so even if they have internal services, many outsource at least a portion of their questions to customer care centers.

Even when legitimate, consumer sentiment regarding outbound calls is waning because of the prevalence of robocalls and scams. Most customer care centers generate the bulk of revenue from inbound call services.

Debt collection services often require little specialized knowledge, so companies across sectors are often happy to outsource them. Still, getting and keeping a client on the phone for such calls can be difficult, especially when using automated tech.

Consumer spending, formally personal consumption expenditure, measures the total amount Americans spend on services and new goods and net purchases of used goods, both domestically and abroad. Consumer spending continues to strengthen as consumer confidence in the economy causes people to spend money on durable goods and discretionary items. With more demand for such items in the economy, businesses will invest in call center services to increase sales and gain market share.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Communications businesses primarily consist of prepaid and postpaid wireless and hardline telecommunications providers. Because of the high rates of competition in these fields, most compete based on the quality of customer service, making the use of customer care centers vital. A greater number of telecommunications companies are opting to open internal divisions to handle customer care services, causing this segment's revenue share to shrink slightly.

The technology market segment includes businesses creating and distributing hardware, software, networking and other technological services and products. Because of the complex nature of such businesses, tech support is a key service needed by most customers. Customer care centers generate the lion's share of revenue from tech-based companies, and the segment will remain prominent. While some tech companies have internal departments handling customer care, many are insufficient, especially for larger businesses. The tech market is quick to adopt automated services, but these have yet to fully replace the services offered by customer care centers.

The financial institutions that use the industry's services include businesses such as investment and commercial banks, securities dealers, credit card issuers, insurance operations and other providers. Financial institutions use customer care centers for a range of services, ranging from debt collection answering general questions to debt collection and cross-selling services. Most financial institutions opt to outsource these services, preferring to focus attention on core functions, so demand from these companies comprises a

The retail and consumer market consists of businesses manufacturing durable and discretionary consumer goods, consumer services companies and online and big-box retailers. The needs of retail businesses are typically less specialized than those of tech or finance companies. The segment is a prime target of newer or more generalized customer care centers, whose employees have less specialization.

Customer care centers serve other sectors of the US economy, including healthcare, transportation, leisure, hospitality, utilities and the government. Because this segment covers so many branches of the economy, it tends to capture a steady proportion of revenue. Some sectors require more specialized customer care centers. This is particularly true for healthcare businesses. The public sector tends to handle customer care needs internally but has increasingly outsourced these services over the past few years.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast region is home to the highest share of customer care centers, with Florida being the top state for providers in the United States. The region contains the largest proportion of the nation's population because of the prevalence of large states such as Georgia, Florida, Virginia and North Carolina.

The West region contains the second-highest share of care centers, with California alone containing nearly one-tenth of establishments. California is home to several major cities, which prove attractive to care centers. A large population equals many potential workers for customer care centers to hire, along with elevated business activity that raises demand for the industry's services. The region's concentration of technology companies means it's primed for care centers since many of these businesses outsource the industry's services.

The Southwest region has a higher share of care centers than its proportion of the total population, but the Great Lakes and Mid-Atlantic regions lag slightly behind. Lower rent costs in Southwest states such as Texas attract new customer care centers looking to keep costs low, but regions like the Mid-Atlantic are often too pricey for budding businesses. The number of growing major cities in Texas will continue attracting new customer care centers, causing the Southwest to become a new hub.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The Telephone Consumer Protection Act (TCPA) was passed in 1991 by congress to reduce and restrict the use of robocalls in call center operations. While many find loopholes around this act, it protects consumers on the National Do Not Call Registry and restricts unsolicited calls to residential and cellular telephones, along with text messages.

The National Do Not Call Registry is enforced by the Federal Trade Commission (FTC). Consumers can willingly add their phone numbers to the Registry, which prevents call centers from contacting them with unsolicited messages and calls. Many less reputable call centers disregard the Registry, calling numbers regardless.

Customer care centers primarily employ part-time workers, while the industry's few full-time employees are almost entirely paid an hourly wage. As a result, centers must adhere to regulations passed down by the Department of Labor, which are included in the Fair Labor Standards Act. Such rules and regulations primarily pertain to fair pay, equal rights and youth employment.

basis_points.basis_description: The most successful customer care centers tend to cater to specific verticals of markets, specializing in specific services. Others opt for a wide-range of services, but these tend to be the largest players.

Many care centers compete based on quality of service. Downstream businesses have many options when choosing customer care centers, including substitutes such as internal divisions, so the most successful centers typically boast reliable, highly skilled employees.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Large international customer care centers exist but are rare
concentration_points.concentration_description: A few large care centers account for high shares of revenue, but these are the exception rather than the rule. Since most customer care centers have just one location and employ less than 20 employees, market share concentration is low.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Care Centers with Higher Concentrations Tend to Expand Through Acquisitions
concentration_points.concentration_description: Few large customer care centers balloon to such sizes through organic growth. Acquisitions provide a key opportunity for expansion, as a care center focused on one market can grow to cater to several markets by acquiring companies focused on different verticals.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Labor expenses are substantial, far outweighing the cost of capital to start a customer call center. Though the prevalence of automated technologies is rising, most rely on physical workers. As a result, wages account more than half of the average center's revenue.

volatility_points.volatility_title: TIGHTER REGULATIONS RESULT IN GREATER OFFSHORING TRENDS
volatility_points.volatility_description: When foreign businesses bring customer care centers to the United States, revenue typically increases. When domestic companies outsource customer care work abroad, demand for the industry's services declines. More frequently, businesses have opted to offshore customer call centers to reduce costs since other countries have more loose labor regulations. A more favorable regulatory environment can lure businesses back to the United States, but few regulatory bodies enact policies that result in such outcomes. Rising offshoring activity has made the industry's performance much more uneven, enhancing revenue volatility during the current period.

volatility_points.volatility_title: RISING E-COMMERCE ACTIVITY BENEFITS CALL CENTERS
volatility_points.volatility_description: When businesses rely heavily on online sales, they tend to employ customer care centers in greater numbers since less emphasis is placed on physical locations and employees. Many businesses will hire third-party call centers rather than open divisions of their own to mitigate costs. Rising e-commerce activity has benefitted customer care centers. Despite this positive development, call centers risk losing business to internal departments when online platforms become too big. Since higher e-commerce sales may spur or hinder the industry's performance, their rapid growth has boosted revenue volatility during the current period.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: CALL MANAGEMENT TECHNOLOGIES HELP CENTERS REDUCE WAIT TIMES
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Customer call centers rely on positive customer experiences to retain business. By implementing management technologies to reduce wait times and enable customers to input information before being connected to live representatives, they can increase customer satisfaction. Many management technologies exist, but finding the right one for a specific center can require some trial and error.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: LEVERAGING BURGEONING ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE (AI) TECHNOLOGY IS KEY
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: New AI technologies could make or break customer call centers. The most successful providers integrate these technologies into their systems rather than fighting change and ultimately being replaced by these innovations. Many care centers can reduce wage costs through proper implementation of these technologies and boost customer satisfaction.

FAQs.question: Has the trend in business outsourcing positively impacted your company? Do you see this trend continuing in the future?
FAQs.answer: The trend of outsourcing has helped the industry. As companies need call center support services, many outsource to the industry. Though large corporations remain the biggest spenders, small businesses can also take advantage.

FAQs.question: Has competition from low-wage countries hurt your business?
FAQs.answer: While foreign competition has increased in recent years, the industry has typically held its own against low-wage countries. For example, some major players significantly increased their operational presence in the US. However other companies have deceased their presence in the US.

FAQs.question: Does your business have to be located nearby key consumer or client markets?
FAQs.answer: It's best to have operations spread over a large geographic area. The most successful companies operate call centers 24 hours a day, seven days a week. Also, a wide geographic spread protects from suspended operations caused by natural disasters or other emergencies.

FAQs.question: Has your company implemented practices to lower purchasing costs?
FAQs.answer: Purchase costs are typically low for customer care centers. The largest expense for companies is wages. Companies can decrease purchase costs by allowing more employees to work from home, which decreases spending in the office.

FAQs.question: Are web-based technologies, such as online document storage and video conferencing hurting your business?
FAQs.answer: Web-based technologies helped companies provide services to customers. For example, troubleshooting and technical challenges have been made easier to solve as technology has improved communication between customers and support staff.

FAQs.question: Does your company use mobile applications to improve client services and consumer experience?
FAQs.answer: While this report covers only call centers, some players provide services using a mobile app, SMS-based system or a built-in add-on to a client's mobile app.

FAQs.question: Is your business responsible for safeguarding customer information?
FAQs.answer: Companies should follow state and federal privacy laws, along with the terms and conditions of the clients they represent.

FAQs.question: Have energy-efficiency regulations positively impacted your business?
FAQs.answer: Environmental regulation has had little impact on this industry. This is a service-based industry, which means there's no production of a physical product, limiting the need for environmental regulation.

FAQs.question: Do you have any challenges with customers paying on time?
FAQs.answer: Companies typically set up contracts with other companies, which may include timing and frequency of payments. Players should ensure that the client is bound by a contract in order to protect itself.

FAQs.question: How frequently does your company purchase new equipment?
FAQs.answer: The industry very rarely purchases any significant new equipment. Computers are the norm, but short of a significant expansion, new equipment is purchased on an as-needed basis.

FAQs.question: Does your company have a recognizable brand? How do you promote word-of-mouth marketing?
FAQs.answer: To ensure steady revenue and cash flow, customer care center companies need secure contracts with major clients. These clients, in turn, commonly opt for customer care centers with an established reputation and track record.

FAQs.question: Do you have incentive programs to retain quality personnel?
FAQs.answer: To provide good services and remain competitive, players need to have access to high-quality personnel management.

FAQs.question: How quickly can new technology be adopted? Does your company keep up to date with the latest technology?
FAQs.answer: Customer care centers must constantly find new and better ways to apply the increased functionality and flexibility of technology to improve their customer management services and provide value to their clients.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor fluctuations in corporate profit? How do changes in the levels of corporate profit directly impact your business?
FAQs.answer: As corporate profit rises, clients can increase their spending on telemarketing services, consequently raising revenue.

FAQs.question: How does a rise in e-commerce sales affect your company? How do you take advantage of this increase?
FAQs.answer: A significant share of revenue is derived from the retail market, with the majority generated from e-commerce. Online consumers, who often inquire about shipment details and returns, often need more customer service support than shoppers in physical stores.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor fluctuations in consumer spending? How is your business affected by consumer spending levels?
FAQs.answer: With more demand for such items in the economy, businesses will invest in call center services to increase sales and gain market share.
